grateful for support|work=NewsComAu|accessdate=18 July 2015|date=26 March 2013}} for "board and lodging" expenses{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/kidnapped-australian-warren-rodwell-freed-by-philippines-terrorists-after-15-months-20130322-2gm30.html|title=Kidnapped Australian Warren Rodwell freed by Philippines terrorists after 15 months|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=23 March 2013|accessdate=21 February 2015}} by his siblings, Rodwell was released on 23 March 2013.{{cite web|url=http://video.au.msn.com/watch/video/472-days-in-captivity/x2mfhai?cpkey=d977c3f7-ec0b-4b03-a871-c20bd9b36189%257c%257c%257c%257c|title=Video - msn Australia, with Outlook.com, Skype, and news|publisher=MSN|accessdate=13 November 2014}} By the end of his 15 months as a hostage in the [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao]], Rodwell had lost about 30 kilograms in weight.{{cite web|url=http://foreignminister.gov.au/releases/2013/bc_mr_130323.html|title=Warren Rodwell|author=Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2014}} Rodwell's biography, ''472 Days Captive of the Abu Sayyaf - The Survival of Australian Warren Rodwell'' by [[Bob East]], describes ASG operational methods and practices, as well as the physical, mental, and psychological aspects of Rodwell's survival techniques. Crowdsourcing for ransom, and social media (such as, [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]]) were used by Abu Sayyaf during negotiations. In her 2013 book ''From Bin Laden To Facebook: 10 Days Of Abduction, 10 Years Of Terrorism'', [[Maria Ressa]] states "Social media is changing what was once a closed dialogue between kidnappers, their victims and governments." On 16 June 2014, suspects Jimmy Nurilla (alias Doc) and Bakrin Haris were arrested. Both reportedly worked under Basilan-based Abu Sayyaf leader Khair Mundos and Furuji Indama.{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/612248/2-suspected-abu-sayyaf-men-believed-to-belong-to-bandits-notorious-faction|title=2 suspected Abu Sayyaf men believed to belong to bandits' notorious faction|author=Liza Jocson|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=18 June 2014|accessdate=29 April 2017}} Authorities believed Nurilla and Haris took part in the Rodwell kidnapping, as well as the separate abduction of US citizen Gerfa Yeatts Lunsman and her son Kevin in 2012. In January 2015, ''[[Mindanao Examiner]]'' newspaper reported the arrest of Barahama Ali{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/officials-seek-negotiator-for-talks-with-kidnappers-20111215-1owyq.html|title=Officials seek negotiator for talks with kidnappers|work=Inquirer.net|accessdate=21 March 2017}} kidnap gang sub-leaders linked to the kidnapping of Rodwell, who was seized by at least 5 gunmen (disguised as policemen), and eventually handed over or sold by the kidnappers to the Abu Sayyaf in Basilan province.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindanaoexaminer.com/news.php?news_id=20150116224746|title=Mindanao Examiner - Warren Rodwell kidnapper arrested in Zamboanga province|accessdate=20 January 2015}} In May 2015, ex-[[Philippine National Police]] (PNP) officer Jun A. Malban, alias Michael Zoo,{{cite news|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/kidnap-leader-arrested-in-zamboanga-sibugay/281241/|title=Kidnap leader arrested in Zamboanga Sibugay|work=RTE|date=21 August 2016|accessdate=4 February 2018}} was arrested in [[Kota Kinabalu]], [[Malaysia]], for the crime of "Kidnapping for Ransom" after Rodwell identified him as the negotiator/spokesperson. Further PNP investigation revealed that Malban is the cousin of Abu Sayyaf leaders Khair and Borhan Mundos (both of whom were arrested in 2014).{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/04/17/15/nbi-files-charges-vs-abu-bandits-gensan-bombing|title=Media Release: NBI files charges vs Abu bandits for Gensan bombing|publisher=ABS-CBN News|date=17 April 2015|access-date=16 August 2015}} The director of the Anti-Kidnapping Group (AKG) stated that Malban's arrest resulted from close co-ordination by the PNP, [[National Bureau of Investigation (Philippines)]] and Presidential Anti-Organized Crime Commission with the Malaysian counterparts and through [[Interpol]].{{cite web|url=http://pnp.gov.ph/portal/index.php/press-news-releases/more-media-news/39-national-headquarters/2615-ex-cop-arrested-in-malaysia-for-kidnapping-of-australian-national|title=Media Release: EX-COP ARRESTED IN MALAYSIA FOR KIDNAPPING OF AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL|publisher=PNP-AKG Press Release|date=18 May 2015|access-date=19 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713201705/http://pnp.gov.ph/portal/index.php/press-news-releases/more-media-news/39-national-headquarters/2615-ex-cop-arrested-in-malaysia-for-kidnapping-of-australian-national|archivedate=13 July 2015|df=dmy-all}} In January 2018, Rodwell attended a court hearing for Malban and others in [[Ipil, Zamboanga Sibugay]], pursuant to a Supreme Court petition to transfer his case for security reasons to a court in either [[Manila]] or [[Zamboanga City]].{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/961363/australian-kidnap-victim-seeks-case-transfer|title=Australian kidnap victim seeks case transfer|work=Inquirer.net|access-date=19 January 2018}} In August 2015, Edeliza Sumbahon Ulep,{{cite web|url=http://www.zamboangatimes.ph/top-news/15773-suspect-in-2012-aussie-kidnapping-in-ipil-nabbed.html|title=Suspect in 2012 Aussie kidnapping in Ipil nabbed|publisher= Zamboanga Times 14 Aug 2015|accessdate=16 August 2015}} alias Gina Perez, was arrested at [[Trento, Agusan del Sur]] during a joint manhunt operation by police and military units. Ulep was tagged as the ransom courier in the kidnapping.{{cite web|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/zamboanga/local-news/2015/08/13/abu-sayyafs-ransom-courier-falls-424436|title=Abu Sayyafs' ransom courier falls|publisher=Sun Star Zamboanga|date=13 August 2015|access-date=16 August 2015}} In August 2016, ''[[The Manila Times]]'' reported the arrest of the kidnap-for-ransom group of Barahama Alih sub-leader, Hasim Calon alias Husien (also a notorious drug dealer), in his hideout in Tenan village in Ipil town. Hasim Calon was involved in Rodwell's abduction. Earlier in 2016, police forces killed Waning Abdulsalam, a former MILF leader, in the village of Singkilon. Abdulsalam was one of the most wanted criminals in the southern Philippines, and connected to ASG. He was linked to the kidnappings of Rodwell in 2011, Irish missionary Michael Sinnott in 2009 in Pagadian City, and Italian Catholic priest Giancarlo Bossi in Zamboanga del Sur's Payao town in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/kidnap-leader-arrested-in-zamboanga-sibugay/281241|title=Kidnap leader arrested in Zamboanga Sibugay|publisher=The Manila Times|date=21 August 2016|accessdate=23 August 2016}} In February 2018, Abu Sayyaf sub-commander Nurhassan Jamiri was reported by Malaysia regional intelligence sources as one of three gunmen killed in a gunfight with police in [[Sabah]]. Jamiri was atop the Philippines' most wanted list and implicated in dozens of ransom kidnappings including Rodwell.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/abu-sayyaf-leader-shot-dead-in-sabah-report|title=Abu Sayyaf leader shot dead in Sabah: Report|publisher=The Straits Times|date=1 March 2018|access-date=2 March 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://mindanaoexaminer.com/notorious-sayyaf-leader-who-escaped-basilan-is-slain-in-sabah-clash/|title=Notorious Sayyaf leader who escaped Basilan is slain in Sabah clash|publisher=Mindanao Examiner|date=1 March 2018|access-date=2 March 2018}} In March 2018, Jamiri turned up alive when he and thirteen followers surrendered to authorities in Basilan. Over the preceding two years, many Abu Sayyaf bandits had surrendered to authorities in Basilan, Sulu and Tawi-Tawi. More were expected to yield because of the regional government's Program Against Violence and Extremism (PAVE), designed to provide opportunities and interventions, including psychosocial sessions, medical check-ups, introduction to farming systems, and expository tours outside the island provinces to facilitate the reintegration of former combatants into society.{{cite news|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/killed-sayyaf-leader-surrenders-in-basilan/389139//|title='Killed' Sayyaf leader surrenders in Basilan|publisher=Manila Times|date=29 March 2018|access-date=13 April 2018}} In April 2018, Rodwell lauded the surrenders and reintegration program, but said he would not interfere with the legal processing of any charges already filed against anyone involved with his own kidnapping.{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/979893/talk-to-abu-sayyaf-australian-kidnap-victim-urges-govt|title= Talk to Abu Sayyaf, Australian kidnap victim urges gov't|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=4 April 2018|access-date=13 April 2018}} =====2012 European bird watchers===== On 1 February, 2012, two European bird watchers were seized on Tawi Tawi island. Swiss Lorenzo Vinciguerra escaped in December 2014 as government troops attacked the jungle camp where he was captive on the island of Jolo. Vinciguerra was shot by rebels as he escaped; however, his injuries were non-life-threatening.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-30358073|title=Swiss hostages escapes Abu Sayyaf captors in Philippines|newspaper=BBC News|date=6 December 2014|accessdate=29 January 2018}} Dutch captive Ewold Horn was reportedly 'very sick and very weak' and unable to escape.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2863341/Swiss-photographer-held-hostage-Islamist-extremists-two-years-escapes-grabbing-machete-cutting-captor-s-throat-dramatic-break-freedom.html|title=Swiss photographer held hostage by Islamist extremists for two years escapes by grabbing machete and cutting captor's throat in dramatic break for freedom|publisher=Daily Mail Australia|date=6 December 2014|accessdate=29 January 2018}} The whereabouts of Horn remain unknown.{{cite web|url=https://thediplomat.com/2016/09/philippine-militancy-in-the-spotlight-with-freed-norwegian-hostage/|title=Philippine Militancy in the Spotlight with Freed Norwegian Hostage|publisher=The Diplomat by Luke Hunt |date=20 September 2016|accessdate=29 January 2018}} =====2012 Mayor Jeffrey Lim Kidnapping===== On 2 April, 2012, Mayor Jeffrey Lim of [[Salug, Zamboanga del Norte]] was kidnapped by ten armed men disguised as policemen. Lim was reportedly handed over to Abu Sayyaf. On 6 November, he was freed near [[Zamboanga City]] after payment of P1.3M ($US25,000) ransom. On 9 August, 2013, a Mindanao Pagadian Frontline report named a "Sehar Muloc" aka "Red Eye" as a suspect in the 2012 kidnapping of Mayor Jeffrey Lim.{{cite news|url= http://www.mindanews.com/top-stories/2015/10/suspect-in-dipolog-kidnapping-was-nabbed-in-2013-for-kidnapping/|title=Suspect in Dipolog kidnapping was nabbed in 2013 for kidnapping|publisher=MindaNews|date=11 October 2015|accessdate=8 February 2018}}{{cite news|url= http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/302446/town-mayor-from-zamboanga-del-norte-freed-after-p1-3m-ransom|title=Town mayor from Zamboanga del Norte freed after P1.3M ransom|publisher=Inquirer.net|date=6 November 2012|accessdate=8 February 2018}} Abner Gumandol, alias Sehar Muloc and Red Eye, was said to be the leader of a criminal syndicate called the Muloc Group. Gumandol was arrested on 12 June 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com:8080/nation/2016/06/13/1592224/suspect-ex-priests-kidnap-falls|title=Suspect in ex-priest's kidnap falls|publisher=The Star|date=13 June 2016|accessdate=8 February 2018}} =====2014 Kabasalan ZSP kidnapping===== On 11 September, 2014, Chinese national Li Pei Zhei was abducted by four gunmen in [[Kabasalan, Zamboanga Sibugay]] and taken to Basilan. He was released in Sitio Lugay-Lugay, Barangay Naga-Naga, [[Alicia, Zamboanga Sibugay]] on 5 November 2014.{{cite web|url=http://pro9.pnp.gov.ph/index.php/public-relations/news-release/485-chinese-kidnap-victim-freed-in-sibugay|title=CHINESE KIDNAP VICTIM FREED IN SIBUGAY|publisher=Philippine National Police|date=6 November 2014|accessdate=2 February 2018}} Police subsequently charged Ibni Basaludin, Yug Enriquez, Brahama Ali, and Ging-Ging Calon, all residents of Barangay Tenan, [[Ipil, Zamboanga Sibugay]] with kidnapping with serious illegal detention.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindanews.com/top-stories/2014/11/4-charged-for-chinese-businessmans-kidnap-in-zambo-sibugay/|title=4 charged for Chinese businessman's kidnap in Zambo Sibugay|publisher=MindaNews|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=2 February 2018}} =====2015 Roseller Lim ZSP kidnapping===== On 24 January, 2015, Korean national Nwi Seong Hong was abducted by armed men in [[Roseller Lim, Zamboanga Sibugay]] Province. The victim's son, Abby, escaped after he fought off the kidnappers.{{cite news|url= http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/11/02/1517439/kidnapped-korean-found-dead-sulu|title=Kidnapped Korean found dead in Sulu|work=The Philippine Star|accessdate=30 January 2018|date=2 November 2015}} According to intelligence information from the JTG-SULU, the captors of were Algabsy Misaya, Idang Susukan, Alden Bagade and Mohammad Salud alias Ama Maas, Indanan-based members led by sub-leaders Isang Susukan and Anga Adji.{{cite web|url=http://philexaminer.com/?p=2089|title=Korean kidnap victim found dead in Jolo - The Philippine Examiner|work=The Philippine Examiner|date=November 2015}}{{cite news|url= https://www.rappler.com/nation/111350-korean-victim-nwi-seong-hong-found-dead|title=Korean kidnap victim found dead in Sulu|work=Rappler|accessdate=30 January 2018|date=1 November 2015}} On 31 October, 2015, the body of 74 year old Nwi Seong Hong was found in Barangay Bangkal, [[Patikul, Sulu]]. Investigators said the victim died due to severe illness. =====2015 Samal Island kidnappings===== [[File:Rodrigo Duterte welcomes Kjartan Sekkingstad.jpg|thumb|Kjartan Sekkingstad (left), one of the people kidnapped by the ASG in Samal Island in 2015, meets with President [[Rodrigo Duterte]] (right) after his release from ASG captivity.]] On 21 September, 2015, Canadians [[Robert Hall (Canadian)|Robert Hall]] and [[John Ridsdel]], as well as Norwegian Kjartan Sekkingstad, and (Hall's girlfriend) Marites Flor; a Filipino woman, were abducted on Samai island near Davao.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/22/gunmen-abduct-two-canadian-tourists-from-southern-philippines-resort|title=Canadian tourists among four abducted by gunmen at Philippines resort|work=Reuters|publisher=The Guardian|date=22 September 2015|accessdate=22 September 2016}} Ridsdel was beheaded by Abu Sayyaf on 25 April 2016 following a ransom deadline.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/hostage-philippines-ridsdel-militants-1.3551416|title=Family devastated after John Ridsdel killed by captors in Philippine|publisher=CBC|date=25 April 2016|accessdate=25 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/pm-outraged-by-killing-of-canadian-in-philippines-1.2873288|title=PM 'outraged' by killing of Canadian in Philippines|author=Josh Dehaas|publisher=CTV News|date=25 April 2016|accessdate=25 April 2016}} ASG reportedly demanded more than $8.1 million for Ridsdel and the others.{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-government-was-very-directly-involved-in-negotiating-for-john-ridsdel-bob-rae-says|title=Canadian government was 'very directly involved' helping John Ridsdel's family: Bob Rae|publisher=National Post|accessdate=30 July 2016|date=2016-04-26}} On 3 May, 2016, a video of the Ridsdel execution was released, along with new demands for the remaining hostages.{{cite web|url=http://www.zerocensorship.com/t/uncensored-philippines-news/261818-isis-affiliate-abu-sayyaf-beheading-execution-of-canadian-john-ridsdel-in-the-philippines-video|title=WATCH: ISIS Pledged Terror Group Abu Sayyaf Beheading Execution Of Canadian Hostage John Ridsdel - Video|publisher=Zero Censorship|accessdate=30 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/05/03/terror-group-releases-video-of-canadian-hostage-s-beheading-in-the-philippines_n_9828928.html|title=John Ridsdel Death: Militants Release Video Of Canadian Hostage's Beheading In Philippines|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=3 May 2016|accessdate=3 May 2016}} A masked captor said, "Note to the Philippine government and to the Canadian government: The lesson is clear. John Ridsdel has been beheaded. Now there are three remaining captives here. If you procrastinate once again the negotiations, we will behead this all anytime".{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/we-will-behead-this-all-anytime-full-transcript-of-new-abu-sayyaf-video-showing-three-hostages|title='We will behead this all anytime': Full transcript of new Abu Sayyaf video showing three hostages|publisher=National Post|accessdate=30 July 2016|date=2016-05-03}} On 15 May, Hall appeared in a new video, announcing that he and Norwegian Kjartan Sekkingstad would be decapitated at 3pm on Monday 13 June absent a ransom of $16 million. Both hostages wore orange coveralls, similar to hostages in videos produced by [[ISIL]], to which Abu Sayyaf had previously pledged allegiance.{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-hostage-dies-on-june-13-unless-16-million-ransom-paid-filipino-terrorist-group-abu-sayyaf-says|title=Canadian hostage dies on June 13 unless $16 million ransom paid, says Filipino terrorist group Abu Sayyaf|publisher=National Post|accessdate=30 July 2016|date=2016-05-16}} The deadline passed. Hall was beheaded.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-06-14/canada-government-believes-abu-sayyaf-hostage-has-been-killed/7507028|title=Philippines confirms execution of Canadian hostage Robert Hall by Abu Sayyaf|publisher=ABC News|date=13 June 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}} On 24 June, Abu Sayyaf released Filipina Marites Flor. She was subsequently flown to Davao to meet President-elect Rodrigo Duterte. Duterte said he directed negotiations with the Abu Sayyaf. He did not elaborate.{{cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/regional/2016/06/24/Abu-Sayyaf-frees-Filipina-hostage.html|title=Abu Sayyaf frees Filipina hostage|publisher=CNN Philippines|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}} On 17 September, 2016, remaining hostage Norwegian Kjartan Sekkingstad was released on Jolo island. Abu Ramie, an ASG spokesman, claimed $638,000 was paid as ransom.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/abu-sayyaf-frees-norwegian-hostage-kjartan-sekkingstad-160917112112583.html|title=Abu Sayyaf frees Norwegian hostage Kjartan Sekkingstad|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=19 September 2016}} =====2015 Dipolog City kidnapping===== On 7 October, 2015, Italian national and pizza restaurant owner Rolando del Torchio was kidnapped in [[Dipolog|Dipolog City]], capital of [[Zamboanga del Norte]] Province. On 8 April, 2016, Del Torchio was released and found at [[Jolo]] port aboard MV KC Beatrice bound for [[Zamboanga City]] after his family paid P29 million ($US650,000) in ransom.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-09/former-italian-priest-freed-by-aby-sayaf-militants/7313488|title=Abu Sayaf militants release former Italian priest Rolando Del Torchio from captivity in Philippines|work=ABC News Australia|date=9 April 2016|accessdate=4 February 2018}} ====In Malaysia==== {{See also|Cross border attacks in Sabah}} =====2000 Sipadan kidnappings===== {{Main|2000 Sipadan kidnappings}} On 3 May, 2000, Abu Sayyaf guerillas occupied the [[Malaysia]]n dive resort island [[Sipadan]] and took 21 [[hostage]]s, including 10 tourists and 11 resort workers – 19 foreign nationals in total. The hostages were taken to an Abu Sayyaf base in [[Jolo]].{{cite news | title= Abu Sayyaf kidnappings, bombings and other attacks | url= http://www.gmanews.tv/story/154797/abu-sayyaf-kidnappings-bombings-and-other-attacks | work= GMA News | date= 23 August 2007 | accessdate =22 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100422202244/http://www.gmanews.tv/story/154797/abu-sayyaf-kidnappings-bombings-and-other-attacks| archivedate= 22 April 2010 | deadurl= no}} Two Muslim Malaysians were released soon after. Abu Sayyaf made various demands for the release of several prisoners, including [[1993 World Trade Center bombing|1993 World Trade Center bomber]] [[Ramzi Yousef]] and $2.4 million. In July, a Filipino television evangelist and 12 of members of the [[Jesus Miracle Crusade|Jesus Miracle Crusade Church]] offered their help and went as mediators for the relief of other hostages.{{cite web|url=http://jmcim.org|title=jmcim.org|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2014}} They, three French television crew members and a German journalist, all visiting Abu Sayyaf on Jolo, were also taken hostage.{{cite news|author=Freeman Washington|url=http://www.cdnn.info/news/industry/i000910.html|title=Abu Sayyaf Muslim rebels raped Sipadan dive tourist hostages| newspaper=cdnn.info |date=10 September 2000 |accessdate=23 March 2010}} Most hostages were released in August and September 2000, partly due to mediation by Libyan leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] and an offer of $25 million in "development aid".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/898190.stm |title=BBC news.uk |publisher=BBC News |date=28 August 2000 |accessdate=3 April 2012}} Abu Sayyaf conducted a second raid on the island of Pandanan near Sipadan on 10 September and seized three more Malaysians.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdnn.info/special-report/sipadan/sipadan_timeline.html |title=Sipadan Timeline |publisher=cdnn.info |accessdate=3 April 2012}} The Philippine army launched a major offensive on 16 September 2000, rescuing all remaining hostages, except Filipino dive instructor Roland Ullah. He was freed in 2003. Abu Sayyaf coordinated with the Chinese [[14K Triad]] gang in carrying out the kidnappings.{{cite web|url=https://www.diigo.com/item/note/27gb8/g9nm|title=Note : August 10, 2000, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Source says some groups took cuts on P9-M payoff, by Donna S. Cueto|publisher=|accessdate=18 July 2015}} The 14K Triad has militarily supported Abu Sayyaf. =====2013 Pom Pom kidnappings===== On 15 November, 2013, Abu Sayyaf militants raided a [[resort]] on the Malaysian island of [[Pom Pom Island|Pom Pom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/pom-pom-island-tourist-killed-wife-kidnapped-2013-11-16-1.528227|title=Pom Pom Island: Tourist killed, wife kidnapped|publisher=[[Emirates 24/7]]|date=16 November 2013|accessdate=6 April 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20131222000063&cid=1101 |title=Militant group Abu Sayyaf behind Taiwanese woman's kidnapping |publisher=Want China Times |date=22 December 2013 |accessdate=6 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031041945/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20131222000063&cid=1101 |archivedate=31 October 2014 |df=dmy}} During the ambush, Taiwanese citizen Chang An-wei was kidnapped and her husband, Hsu Li-min, was killed.{{cite web |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201312230032.aspx |publisher=Focus Taiwan |title=Kidnapping victim thanks helper for securing release |accessdate=7 June 2014}} Chang was taken to the [[Sulu Archipelago]]. Chang was freed in [[Sulu|Sulu Province]] and returned to Taiwan on 21 December.{{cite web |url= http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/article/1387187/abducted-taiwanese-woman-evelyn-chang-found-southern-philippines|publisher= South China Morning Post|title= Abducted Taiwanese woman Evelyn Chang found in Southern Philippines |accessdate=7 June 2014|date= 2013-12-20}}{{cite news |last= Lewis|first= Leo|date= 5 April 2014|title= Snatched Tourist Faces Torment in Jungle|url= http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/asia/article4054851.ece |newspaper= The Times of London|location= |publisher= |accessdate= 7 June 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2013/12/20/semporna-kidnap-taiwanese-rescued-pom-pom-island-resort.aspx/|title=Semporna kidnap: Rescued - Taiwanese tourist kidnapped from Pom Pom island resort (Update)|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=20 December 2013|accessdate=6 April 2014|author=Farik Zolkepli}} =====2014 Singamata, Baik Island & Kampung Air Sapang kidnappings===== On 2 April, 2014, a kidnap gang believed to originate from Abu Sayyaf militants raided Singamata Reef Resort off [[Semporna]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/04/04/semporna-kidnappers-also-involved-pompom-sipadan/|title=Semporna resort kidnap: Abductors also involved in Pom-Pom and Sipadan incidents, says Esscom chief|publisher=The Star|date=4 April 2014|accessdate=6 April 2014|author=Muguntan Vanar}}{{cite web|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/101571/filipino-resort-worker-chinese-tourist-abducted-in-malaysia|title=Abu Sayyaf men abduct 2 in Malaysia–officials|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=3 April 2014|accessdate=6 April 2014}} [[People's Republic of China|Chinese]] tourist Gao Huayun from [[Shanghai]] and [[Filipino people|Filipino]] resort worker Marcy Dayawan were abducted and taken to the Sulu Archipelago.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/04/03/Semporna-kidnapping-Semporna/|title=Two abducted from resort off Semporna|publisher=The Star|date=3 April 2014|accessdate=6 April 2014|author=Muguntan Vanar}} The two hostages were later rescued after a collaboration between Malaysian and Philippines security forces.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/kidnapped-tourist-resort/1130660.html |title=Kidnapped tourist, resort worker rescued in Malaysia |publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]] |date=31 May 2014 |accessdate=31 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531173414/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/kidnapped-tourist-resort/1130660.html |archivedate=31 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2014/05/women-abducted-from-malaysian-resort-released-2014530225216382478.html|title=Women abducted from Malaysian resort released|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 May 2014|accessdate=31 May 2014}} On 6 May, five Abu Sayyaf gunmen raided a Malaysian [[fish farming|fish farm]] on [[Baik Island]] Sabah, kidnapped the fish farm manager and took him to Jolo island.{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2014/05/06/another-kidnap-in-sabah/|title=Another abduction in Sabah|publisher=[[Free Malaysia Today]]|date=6 May 2014|accessdate=31 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/05/08/Hostage-search-called-off-Officials-get-reports-that-Chinese-national-has-been-taken-to-Jolo/|title=Officials get reports that Chinese national has been taken to Jolo|author1=Muguntan Vanar|author2=Stephanie Lee|publisher=The Star|date=8 May 2014|accessdate=31 May 2014}} He was freed in July with the help of Malaysian negotiators.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/07/11/Man-freed-after-63-days-in-captivity-Msian-negotiators-rescue-fish-farm-manager-from-Abu-Sayyaf-gunm/|title=Malaysian negotiators rescue fish farm manager from Abu Sayyaf gunmen|author1=Ruben Sario|author2=Stephanie Lee|publisher=The Star|date=11 July 2014|accessdate=12 July 2014}} On 16 June, two gunmen believed to be from Abu Sayyaf kidnapped a Chinese fish farm manager and one Filipino worker in Kampung Air Sapang.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1082281|title=Two more kidnapped in Sabah|publisher=[[The Sun (Malaysia)|The Sun]]|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014|author=Charles Ramendran and Bernard Cheah}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/06/16/kunak-kidnap-victim-yells-abductors-not-to-disturb-wife/|title=Kunak kidnap: "Don't disturb my wife. I will follow you"|publisher=The Star|work=Bernama|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014}} The worker managed to escape and disappeared.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/asia/south-east-asia/story/fish-farm-worker-manages-escape-armed-kidnappers-sabah-20140616|title=Fish farm worker manages to escape armed kidnappers in Sabah|publisher=[[The Straits Times]]|work=The Star/[[Asia News Network]]|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=90074|title=Hostage who escaped sought|publisher=Daily Express|date=18 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014}} Meanwhile, the fish farm manager was taken to Jolo.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/06/20/Kidnappers-contact-fish-breeders-wife-No-ransom-demand-was-made/|title=Kidnappers contact fish breeder's wife|publisher=The Star|date=20 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014}} He was released on 10 December.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1264262|title=Fish breeder released by Abu Sayyaf|publisher=The Sun|date=10 December 2014|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Malaysian authorities identified five Filipinos, the "Muktadil brothers", as responsible for these cases. They sold their hostages to the Abu Sayyaf group.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/06/22/Muktadir-kin-mastermind-behind-kidnaps-Sources-Brothers-sell-hostages-to-Abu-Sayyaf/|title=Muktadir kin - mastermind behind kidnaps?|author1=PK Katharason|author2=Muguntan Vanar|author3=Ruben Sario|author4=Stephanie Lee|author5=Philip Golingai|publisher=The Star|date=22 June 2014|accessdate=22 June 2014}} Of the five Muktadil brothers: Mindas Muktadil was killed by Philippine police in May 2015, Kadafi Muktadil was arrested in late 2015, Nixon Muktadil and Brown Muktadil were killed by the Philippine military on 27 September 2016 after they resisted arrest,{{cite web|url=http://m.thesundaily.my/node/397360|title=Philippines: Two militants linked to sailor abductions killed|publisher=The Sun|date=27 September 2016|accessdate=27 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/09/28/kidnap-group-leaders-killed-muktadil-brothers-gunned-down-in-surprise-raid-on-sulu-island/|title=Muktadil Brothers gunned down in surprise raid on Sulu island|author1=Muguntan Vanar|author2=Stephanie Lee|publisher=The Star|date=28 September 2016|accessdate=3 October 2016}} while Badong Muktadil succumbed to his injuries while fleeing after he was shot when his brothers was killed. His body was discovered in a pump boat in Mususiasi.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/09/30/last-of-muktadil-brothers-killed-badong-found-dead-after-military-shootout/|title=Last of Muktadil brothers killed|author=Muguntan Vanar|publisher=The Star|date=30 September 2016|accessdate=3 October 2016}} =====2015 Ocean King Restaurant kidnappings===== On 15 May, 2015, four armed Abu Sayyaf members kidnapped two Malaysian nationals from Ocean King Restaurant in an upscale resort in [[Sandakan]], [[Sabah]] and took them to [[Parang, Sulu]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2015/05/16/kidnapping-incident-in-sabah-recurs/|title=Kidnapping incident in Sabah recurs|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=16 May 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/487930/news/regions/police-abu-sayyaf-linked-to-sabah-kidnap|title=Police: Abu Sayyaf linked to Sabah kidnap|publisher=GMA News|date=15 May 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}} Police identified the leaders of the group behind the abduction as Alhabsy Misaya, Alden Bagade and Angah Adji. On 8 November, Thien Nyuk Fun, the seafood restaurant owner, was released after payment of 30 million pesos ($US675,000) ransom.{{cite web|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/130670/sabah-hostage-released-by-abu-sayyaf-gunmen|title=Sabah hostage released by Abu Sayyaf gunmen|work=The Star/Asia News Network|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=9 November 2015|accessdate=9 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/abu-sayyaf-releases-thien-nyuk-fun-one-of-two-malaysians-taken-from-sabah-restaurant|title=Abu Sayyaf releases Thien Nyuk Fun, one of two Malaysians taken from Sabah restaurant|work=The Straits Times|date=9 November 2015|accessdate=5 February 2018}} The initial agreement of 30 million pesos was reportedly for both hostages; however, a faction within the Abu Sayyaf Group demanded more after Thien Nyuk Fun was released. Further negotiations broke down and the other hostage, electrical engineer Bernard Then, was beheaded on Jolo Island on 17 November.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/11/17/Bernard-then-killed-abu-sayyaf/|title=Malaysian hostage Bernard Then beheaded|author1=Muguntan Vanar|author2=Stephanie Lee|publisher=The Star|date=17 November 2015|accessdate=18 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/11/17/Bernard-Then-beheading-ransom-not-met/|title=Demand for higher ransom led to beheading|publisher=The Star|date=17 November 2015|accessdate=18 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2015/11/17/bernard-then-killed-abu-sayyaf/|title=Malaysian hostage Bernard Then beheaded|work=The Star Online|date=17 November 2015|accessdate=5 February 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/opinion/columnists/one-mans-meat/2015/11/21/why-bernard-then-was-beheaded/|title=Why Bernard Then was beheaded|work=The Star Online|date=21 November 2015|accessdate=5 February 2018}} ====Philippines and Malaysia waters==== =====2014 German sailors kidnapping===== In April 2014, Germans Dr. Stefan Viktor Okonek and Henrike Dielen were captured on their yacht on the high seas near Borneo. Abu Sayyaf threatened to behead one of them. After payment of $US5.6 million in October 2014, the pair were released in Patikul, Sulu.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-militants/philippine-militants-free-two-german-hostages-idUSKCN0I607S20141017|title=Philippine militants free two German hostages|newspaper=Reuters|date=17 October 2014|accessdate=29 January 2018}} =====2016 Local and foreign sailors kidnappings===== On 26 March, 2016, ten [[Indonesian people|Indonesian]] seafarers were held hostage by ASG operating in [[Sulu Archipelago]]. They were abducted from the Brahma 12 tugboat and the Anand 12 barge{{Cite news|url=http://www.marinelink.com/news/indonesian-hostages408407.aspx|title=Ship Owner to Pay Ransom for Indonesian Hostages|date=2016-04-20|work=MarineLink|access-date=2018-01-29|language=en}} near [[Tawi-Tawi province]].{{cite news | title = 10 Indonesian sailors kidnapped in the Philippines | author = Ray Sanchez | work = CNN | date = 29 March 2016 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2016/03/29/asia/philippines-indonesia-sailors-hostage/}} The Indonesian vessels were freighting coal from [[South Borneo]] heading for [[Batangas]] port when hijacked. In April, the Indonesian government announced that the company that owned tugboat ''Brahma 12'' had agreed to pay the 50-million-peso ($1 million) ransom.{{cite news | title = Ship Owner to Pay Ransom for Indonesian Hostages | author = Aiswarya Lakshmi | work = MarineLink.com | date = 20 April 2016 | url = http://www.marinelink.com/news/indonesian-hostages408407.aspx}} On 2 May, they were released.{{cite news | title = 10 Indonesian hostages released by Islamist militant group, president says | author = Tim Hume and Kathy Quiano | work = CNN | date = 2 May 2016 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2016/05/01/asia/indonesia-philippines-abu-sayyaf-hostages/}} On 1 April, four [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] sailors aboard a tugboat from Manila were kidnapped when they arrived near the shore of [[Ligitan Island]]. Their companions, three Myanmar nationals and two Indonesians, were unharmed.{{cite web|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2016/04/03/four-sarawakians-kidnapped/|title=Four Sarawakians kidnapped|author1=Nancy Lai|author2=Margaret Ringgit|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=3 April 2016|accessdate=3 April 2016}} On 8 June, they were released.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/4-malaysians-released-by/2854376.html|title=4 Malaysians released by Abu Sayyaf: Philippine military|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=8 June 2016|accessdate=15 June 2016}} On 15 April, four Indonesian sailors were kidnapped when two Indonesian tugboats from [[Cebu]], ''Henry'' and ''Cristi'', were attacked by Abu Sayyaf militants. While five of the passengers were safe, one was shot before he was rescued.{{cite web|url=http://news.okezone.com/read/2016/04/16/337/1364473/kapal-indonesia-kembali-dibajak-4-wni-diculik-1-ditembak|title=Kapal Indonesia Kembali Dibajak, 4 WNI Diculik & 1 Ditembak|author=Arief Setyadi|language=Indonesian|publisher=Okezone|date=16 April 2016|accessdate=16 April 2016}} They were released on 11 May.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/05/12/abu-sayyaf-releases-four-remaining-ri-hostages.html|title=Abu Sayyaf releases four remaining RI hostages|author1=Ina Parlina|author2=Tama Salim|publisher=The Jakarta Post|date=12 May 2016|accessdate=13 May 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513122712/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/05/12/abu-sayyaf-releases-four-remaining-ri-hostages.html|archivedate=13 May 2016|deadurl=yes}} A group of concerned Filipinos in Sabah urged Philippine president-elect [[Rodrigo Duterte]] to intervene for the release of four Malaysians held hostage by Abu Sayyaf. The issue strained the relationship between the Philippines and Malaysia.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=109710|title=Filipinos in Sabah urge Duterte: Help free hostages|publisher=Daily Express|date=13 May 2016|accessdate=13 May 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513123353/http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=109710|archivedate=13 May 2016|deadurl=yes}} On 21 June, seven Indonesian sailors were kidnapped while aboard a tugboat passing through the Sulu Archipelago.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/792201/abu-kidnappers-seize-7-indonesians|title=Abu kidnappers seize 7 Indonesians|author=Estrella Torres|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 July 2016}} On 9 July, three Indonesian fishermen were kidnapped near the coast of Lahad Datu, Sabah, Malaysia {{cite web|url=http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/armed-men-kidnap-three-indonesians-off-sabah-coast/|title=Armed Men Kidnap Three Indonesians Off Sabah Coast|publisher=Jakarta Globe|date=10 July 2016|accessdate=10 July 2016}} and released on 17 September.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/09/174118/three-indonesians-abducted-sabah-waters-freed-militant-abu-sayyaf-group?|title=Three Indonesians abducted in Sabah waters freed by militant Abu Sayyaf group|work=Reuters|publisher=New Straits Times|date=18 September 2016|accessdate=18 September 2016}} On 18 July, five Malaysian sailors were abducted near the coast of Lahad Datu.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/5-malaysian-crewmen/2969950.html|title=5 Malaysian crewmen kidnapped by Abu Sayyaf: Philippine official|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=20 July 2016|accessdate=26 July 2016}} On 3 August, an Indonesian sailor was kidnapped in the waters of Malaysia leaving two other crew members unharmed. This incident was reported by victims on 5 August.{{cite web|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/106126/govt-confirms-one-more-indonesian-abducted-in-malaysian-water|title=Govt confirms one more Indonesian abducted in Malaysian water|author=Heru|publisher=Antara|date=7 August 2016|accessdate=11 August 2016}} Two of the hostages managed to escape after receiving persistent threats of beheading.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/mobile/world/second-indonesian-sailor-manages-to-escape-abu-sayyaf-captors-1.3033492|title=Second Indonesian sailor manages to escape Abu Sayyaf captors|author=Teresa Cerojano|work=The Associated Press|publisher=CTV News|date=18 August 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} On 10 September, three Filipino fishermen were kidnapped on the shores of Pom Pom Island.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/filipino-militants-kidnap-three-fishermen-sabah-waters-3217|title=Filipino militants kidnap three fishermen in Sabah waters|author=Samhati Bhattacharjya|publisher=International Business Times|date=11 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://m.thesundaily.my/node/393969|title=Gunmen kidnaps 3 Filipino fishermen near Pulau Pom Pom|author=Charles Ramendran|publisher=The Sun|date=11 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}} On 22 September, another Indonesian hostage was released.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/indonesia/bahasa/englishedition/147049-abu-sayyaf-hostage-release|title=Another Indonesian hostage released by the Abu Sayyaf|author1=Carmela Fonbuena|author2=Natashya Gutierrez|work=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Rappler|date=22 September 2016|accessdate=25 September 2016}} On 27 September, one Malaysian boat-skipper was kidnapped from his trawler by seven armed militants before the group attacked another Indonesian trawler; however, no kidnappings were committed in the second incident.{{cite web|url=http://m.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/police-believe-filipino-group-raided-sabah-twice-in-same-night|title=Police believe Filipino group raided Sabah twice in same night|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=28 September 2016|accessdate=28 September 2016}} The hostage was released on 1 October, with no ransom demand,{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/10/01/pulau-gaya-kidnap-victim-freed/|title=Fishing boat owner freed by Filipino abductors|author=Muguntan Vanar|publisher=The Star|date=1 October 2016|accessdate=2 October 2016}} along with three Indonesians hostages who were released the same day.{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/10/03/asia-pacific/abu-sayyaf-frees-indonesia-tugboat-trio-three-months-captivity/|title=Abu Sayyaf frees Indonesia tugboat trio after three months in captivity|work=Associated Press|publisher=The Japan Times|date=3 October 2016|accessdate=2 October 2016}} On 21 October, approximately ten Abu Sayyaf militants attacked a South Korean-bound vessel named ''MV Dongbang Gian'' and abducted a South Korean skipper and a Filipino crewman off [[Bongao, Tawi-Tawi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/10/21/abu-sayyaf-attacks-s-korean-ship-abducts-skipper-crewman.html|title=Abu Sayyaf attacks S. Korean ship, abducts skipper, crewman|work=The Associated Press|publisher=Fox News|date=21 October 2016|accessdate=23 October 2016}} On 5 November, German sailor Sabine Merz was shot dead while her husband [[Jürgen Kantner]] was abducted from their yacht off Tanjong Luuk Pisuk in Sabah. On or before 27 February 2017, Kantner was beheaded after a ransom of 30 million pesos ($US600,000) was not paid.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/11/186536/report-german-kidnapped-girlfriend-killed-abu-sayyaf-storm-yacht-sabah-waters|title=Report: German kidnapped, girlfriend killed as Abu Sayyaf storm yacht off Sabah waters|author=Awang Ali Omar|publisher=New Straits Times|date=7 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/587769/news/regions/asg-claims-abducting-german-off-sabah|title=[Female companion found dead in Sulu] ASG claims abducting German off Sabah|publisher=GMA News|date=7 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thelocal.de/20170227/german-hostage-beheaded-by-philippine-islamists|title=German sailor beheaded by Philippine Islamists|publisher=GMA News|date=27 February 2017|accessdate=29 January 2018}} On 11 November, Vietnamese vessel MV Royale 16 with nineteen sailors on board was attacked by Abu Sayyaf near Basilan, abducting six sailors and injuring one. The remaining thirteen sailors were released.{{cite web|url=http://tuoitrenews.vn/society/37957/6-vietnamese-abducted-in-attack-on-cargo-ship-off-philippines|title=6 Vietnamese abducted in attack on cargo ship off Philippines|publisher=Tuổi Trẻ|date=11 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}} On 20 November, two Indonesian fishermen were kidnapped by five gunmen off Lahad Datu.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2016/11/20/philippines-tries-to-intercept-bandits-as-more-indonesians-snatched-at-sea/|title=Philippines tries to intercept bandits as more fishermen snatched off Sabah|author1=Manuel Mogato|author2=Martin Petty|author3=Kim Coghill|work=Reuters|publisher=The Star|date=20 November 2016|accessdate=20 November 2016}} Due to the increase of attacks against foreign vessels by Abu Sayyaf, the governments of Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines agreed to jointly patrol their waters on 5 May 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN0XW0O7|title=Indonesia, Philippines, Malaysia to coordinate against militant pirates|author1=Budi Satriawan|author2=Manuel Mogato|author3=Fergus Jensen|author4=Robert Birsel|newspaper=Reuters|date=5 May 2016|accessdate=6 May 2016}} The three countries formed another agreement on joint air patrols.{{cite web|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/146016/philippines-indonesia-malaysia-agree-on-joint-air-patrols|title=Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia agree on joint air patrols|author=Francis Mangosing|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=3 October 2016|accessdate=3 October 2016}} During the first six months of 2016, Abu Sayyaf made $7.3 million, equivalent to [[Philippine peso|Php]] 353 million, from ransom payoffs.{{cite news | last =Gomez | first =Jim | title = ''Abu Sayyaf got $7.3 million from kidnappings'' | publisher =[[The Washington Post]] | date = 27 October 2016 | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/apnewsbreak-abu-sayyaf-got-7-million-from-kidnappings/2016/10/27/2e93a898-9c19-11e6-b552-b1f85e484086_story.html | accessdate = 27 October 2016}} ===Beheadings=== {{Main|Abu Sayyaf beheading incidents}} As part of its [[kidnapping|kidnap-for-ransom operations]], the Abu Sayyaf has executed some of their male hostages if ransom demands were not met.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/20/how-abu-sayyaf-the-islamist-terror-gang-made-a-business-out-of-b/|title=How Abu Sayyaf makes a business of beheadings as Islamist terror gang releases 'final message' hostage video|author=Philip Sherwell|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=23 May 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}} The group had previously beheaded Christian civilians and other [[kafir]] without demanding ransoms for their release, due to their religious affiliation.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/philippines/1336482/Philippines-rebel-kidnappers-behead-nine-Christian-hostages.html|title=Philippines rebel kidnappers behead nine Christian hostages|author=Alex Spillius|publisher=The Telegraph|date=5 August 2001|accessdate=29 July 2016}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/aug/22/alqaida.terrorism|title=Jehovah's Witnesses beheaded in Philippines|newspaper=The Guardian|date=22 August 2002|accessdate=29 July 2016}} ===Bombings=== ====2004 Superferry 14 Bombing==== {{Main|Superferry 14}} [[Superferry 14]] was a large ferry destroyed by a bomb on 27 February 2004, killing 116 people in the [[Philippines]]' worst terrorist attack and the world's deadliest terrorist attack at sea.{{cite web|last=Rommel C. Banlaoi |title=Maritime Terrorism in Southeast Asia: The Abu Sayyaf Threat |url=http://www.usnwc.edu/getattachment/f54ece77-3d67-4c32-bfaa-02b476a569d8/Maritime-Terrorism-in-Southeast-Asia--The-Abu-Sayy |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920113008/http://www.usnwc.edu/getattachment/f54ece77-3d67-4c32-bfaa-02b476a569d8/Maritime-Terrorism-in-Southeast-Asia--The-Abu-Sayy |archivedate=20 September 2011 }} On that day, the 10,192 [[ton]] ferry sailed out of [[Manila]] with about 900 passengers and crew on board. A television set filled with 8 lb. (4 kilograms) of [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]] had been placed on board. 90 minutes out of port, the bomb exploded. 63 people were killed instantly and 53 were missing and presumed dead. Despite claims from terrorist groups, the blast was initially thought to have been an accident caused by a gas explosion. However, after divers righted the ferry five months after it had sunk, they found evidence of a bomb blast. A man called Redendo Cain Dellosa admitted to planting the bomb for Abu Sayyaf.{{cite web|last=Rommel C. Banlaoi|title=Abu Sayyaf Group: Threat of Maritime Piracy and Terrorism|url=http://www.ppl.nl/plinklet/?sid=bibliographies&ppn=302372067&genre=bookitem&issn=&isbn=0415953200&title=The%20Abu%20Sayyaf%20Group%20:%20Threat%20of%20Maritime%20Piracy%20and%20Terrorism%20/%20Rommel%20C.%20Banlaoi&aulast=Banlaoi&aufirst=Rommel%20C.&au2last=&au2first=&au3last=&au3first=&edlast=&edfirst=&ed2last=&ed2first=&ed3last=&ed3first=&source=Violence%20at%20Sea%20:%20Piracy%20in%20the%20Age%20of%20Global%20Terrorism%20/%20ed.%20by%20Peter%20Lehr&year=2007&volume=&issue=&spage=121-137&bibliography=terrorism&table=terrorism&download=N&scharnier=&extensie=&id=14903&url=}} Six suspects were arrested in connection with the bombing while the masterminds, [[Khadaffy Janjalani]] and [[Abu Sulaiman]], were killed.{{cite book|last=Banlaoi|first=Rommel|title=Philippine Security in the Age of Terror|year=2010|publisher=CRC Press Taylor and Francis|location=New York and London|isbn=978-1-4398-1550-2|pages=1–358}} ====2016 Davao City bombing==== {{Main|2016 Davao City bombing}} On 2 September, 2016, an explosion occurred at a night market in [[Davao City]], Philippines killing at least 15 deaths and injuring 70.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/813881/davao-blast-suspect-identified-bato-says|title=Davao blast suspect identified, Bato says|author=Julliane Love de Jesus|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=8 September 2016|accessdate=8 September 2016|quote=Victims: 40 died and 70 injured.}}{{cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/09/13/pregnant-davao-bombing-victim-dies-in-hospital-death-toll-rises-15.html|title=Pregnant Davao bombing victim dies in hospital; death toll rises to 15|author=Ben O. Tesiorna|publisher=CNN Philippines|date=13 September 2016|accessdate=13 September 2016}} Shortly before the bombing, Abu Sayyaf made a threat following the intensified military operation against them.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-issues-wipe-out-order-against-abu-sayyaf-20160831-gr59dw.html|title=Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte issues 'wipe out' order against Abu Sayyaf|author=Lindsay Murdoch|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=31 August 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/09/02/AFP-vs-Abu-Sayyaf.html|title=AFP taps 7,000-strong force vs. Abu Sayyaf|author=Eimor P. Santos|publisher=CNN Philippines|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/811993/abu-sayyaf-to-bring-fight-to-afp-doorstep|title=Abu Sayyaf to bring fight to AFP doorstep|author=Julie Alipala|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/812066/army-pours-troops-into-pursuit-abus-ready-for-last-war|title=Army pours troops into pursuit; Abus ready for 'last war'|author1=Cynthia D. Balana|author2=Julie Alipala|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} Abu Sayyaf spokesperson Abu Rami was reported to claim responsibility.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/145045-abu-sayyaf-responsibility-davao-explosion|title=Abu Sayyaf claims responsibility for Davao blast – report|publisher=Rappler|date=3 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} He later denied the report and any involvement, saying a group allied to them; the Daulat Ul-Islamiya were responsible.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/812451/abu-sayyaf-disowns-davao-explosion-says-ally-was-behind-attack|title=Abu Sayyaf disowns Davao explosion, says ally was behind attack|author1=Allan Nawal|author2=Julie Alipala|author3=Karlos Manlupig|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} Although the Abu Sayyaf spokesman denied involvement, the Philippine government blame the group. {{quote|This is not the first time that Davao has been sacrificed to the altar of violence. It's always connected with Abu Sayyaf before. They gave a warning. We know that.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/philippines-abu-sayyaf-blamed-attack-davao-city-160903025801696.html|title=Philippines: Abu Sayyaf blamed for attack in Davao City|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=3 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}|[[Rodrigo Duterte]], President of the Philippines}} ==Criticism of attacks against civilians== Sheikh [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] in [[Qatar]] denounced the kidnappings and killings committed by Abu Sayyaf, asserting that they are not part of the dispute between the Abu Sayyaf and the Philippine government. He stated that it is shameful to commit such acts in the name of the Islamic faith, saying that such acts produce backlash against Islam and Muslims.{{cite web|url=http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/gtrec/files/2012/08/gtrec-proceedings-2008-09-bob-east.pdf|title=The Abu Sayyaf in the Archipelago: Discrediting Islam. Abetting USA Foreign Policy|author=Bob East|publisher=Hartford Web Publishing|date=10 May 2000|accessdate=3 April 2016|page=196 (7/15)|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403090208/http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/gtrec/files/2012/08/gtrec-proceedings-2008-09-bob-east.pdf|archivedate=3 April 2016|deadurl=yes}} During the 2000 Sipadan kidnappings, the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] (OIC) condemned the kidnapping and offered to help secure their release. OIC Secretary General [[Azeddine Laraki]], told the Philippine government he was prepared to send an envoy to help save the hostages and issued a statement condemning the rebels. "The Secretary General has pointed out that this operation and the like are rejected by divine laws and that they are neither the appropriate nor correct means to resolve conflicts", the statement said. The terrorism against civilians committed were condemned by MNLF and MILF, who said that Abu Sayyaf strayed from their real paths of struggle, with MILF labelling Abu Sayyaf as "anti-Islam" soon after [[John Ridsdel|Ridsdel]]'s beheading in 2016. MNLF described the group as "causing chaos to their community".{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/2016/08/09/1611720/4-abu-sayyaf-killed-sulu-clash-mnlf|title=4 Abu Sayyaf killed in Sulu clash with MNLF|author=Roel Pareño|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=9 August 2016|accessdate=12 August 2016}} Both Christian and Muslim groups in the Philippines condemned Abu Sayyaf beheadings.{{cite web|url=http://www.ucanews.com/news/christians-muslims-condemn-abu-sayyaf-beheading/79025|title=Christians, Muslims condemn Abu Sayyaf beheading|author=Darwin Wally Wee|publisher=UCA News|date=24 April 2017|accessdate=26 April 2016}} The kidnappings were criticised by [[Indonesia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.republika.co.id/berita/nasional/politik/16/07/28/ob0m9l365-ade-komarudin-merasa-indonesia-terhina-oleh-kelompok-abu-sayyaf|title=Ade Komarudin Merasa Indonesia Terhina oleh Kelompok |archivedate=29 July 2016|deadurl=yes}} On 14 July 2016, a group of Indonesian protesters gathered in front of the Philippine Embassy in Indonesia, holding banners that read "Go to hell Philippines and Abu Sayyaf" and "Destroy the Philippines and Abu Sayyaf" due to what was seen as the lack of action from the [[Government of the Philippines|Philippine government]], who seems unable to defeat the militants and protect foreign citizens.{{cite web|url=http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/protest-philippine-embassy-jakarta-hostage-crisis-worsens/|title=Protest at Philippine Embassy in Jakarta 2016|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/indonesia/bahasa/englishedition/139709-abu-sayyaf-duterte-sailors-rally|title='Go to hell Philippines': Indonesian 2016|deadurl=yes}} The group demanded a large scale military operation to destroy the Abu Sayyaf, of which the [[Indonesian Armed Forces|Indonesian military]] before also have proposing to send their July 2016|deadurl=yes}} ==Military operations== The [[Armed Forces of the Philippines|Philippine military]] has engaged Abu Sayyaf since the 1990s.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1370&dat=19951215&id=ko0mAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1AoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2570,2778271|title=Sayyaf holds 3, not 2, hostages|publisher=Manila Standard|date=15 December rescue|publisher=Sun Journal|date=4 May 2000|accessdate=30 July 2016}} Under President Duterte, the Philippine government sought a [[Bangsamoro peace process|peace agreement]] with the MNLF and MILF, but not the "bunch of criminals" in Abu Sayyaf.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/575498/news/nation/abu-sayyaf-excluded-from-duterte-s-peace-initiatives|title=('NO TALKS WITH CRIMINALS') Abu Sayyaf excluded from Duterte's peace initiatives|author=Katharina Charmaine Alvarez|publisher=GMA News|date=28 July 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}} The Philippine military intensified operations in 2003, following the arrest of a [[Filipino-American]] who was alleged to have sold illegal weapons to the group. The suspect was tagged by US authorities as "one of the United States' most wanted fugitives". He was then deported by the Philippine government to face legal action in the US.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/226844/fil-am-accused-supplying-weapons-sayyaf-deported|title=Fil-Am accused of supplying weapons to Sayyaf deported|work=Associated Press|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=6 November 2003|accessdate=30 July 2016}} On 29 July 2016, the military gained control of an Abu Sayyaf stronghold in [[Tipo-Tipo, Basilan|Tipo-Tipo]]. The Philippine military pledged to eliminate Abu Sayyaf.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/801141/look-scout-rangers-gain-control-of-abu-sayyaf-position-in-basilan|title=LOOK: Scout Rangers gain control of Abu Sayyaf position in Basilan|author=Frances Mangosing|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=30 July 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}} On 25 August, President Duterte ordered the group to be "destroyed" after it beheaded a teenager. Following the incident, the Philippine military sent thousands of troops to fight and destroy Abu Sayyaf. Filipino Army Major Filemon Tan said, "The order of the president is to search and destroy the Abu Sayyaf so that's what we are doing".{{cite web|url=http://mindanation.com/3885/troops-kill-11-abu-sayyaf-members/|title=Troops kill 11 Abu Sayyaf members|publisher=MINDANATION |date=26 August 2016|accessdate=26 August 2016}} Both MNLF and MILF began helping to suppress [[extremism]] in Mindanao, which helps the peace process for both groups. Philippine security forces collaborated with Malaysia and Indonesia to maintain security in the Sulu Sea.{{cite web|url=http://english.astroawani.com/malaysia-news/malaysia-philippines-establish-forward-base-border-112342|title=Malaysia, Philippines to establish forward base at border|author=Hafiz web|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/105659/indonesia-malaysia-the-philippines-finalizing-sop-for-joint-patrols|title=Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines finalizing SOP for joint patrols|date=14 July 2016|publisher=[[Antara (news agency)|Antara]]|accessdate=30 July 2016}}The [[Government of Indonesia|Indonesian government]] proposed to station [[Indonesian Army|army]] units in Mindanao to launch a major offensive against Abu Sayyaf.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/academia/2016/07/14/qa-rethinking-indonesias-military-operation-in-southern-philippines.html|title=Q&A: July 2016|deadurl=yes}} The Indonesian government called on the [[Malaysian Army|Malaysian]] and [[Philippine Army|Philippine]] armies to launch combined land attacks together on Mindanao, while at the same time urging the Philippine government to allow Indonesia and Malaysia military forces to enter Philippine territory.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/jakarta-proposes-3-nation-land-ops-against-abu-sayyaf|title=Jakarta proposes 3-nation land ops against Abu Sayyaf|publisher=The Straits Times|date=4 2016|deadurl=yes}} The [[Vietnam People's Armed Forces|Vietnamese military]] started to hold military exercises against Abu Sayyaf (known locally as "pirates" by the Vietnamese) following the repeat The Philippine military provided one battalion to go against each subgroup.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/09/05/1620711/army-battalion-going-after-each-abu-sayyaf-leader|title=One Army battalion going after each Abu Sayyaf leader|author=Roel Pareño|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=5 September 2016|accessdate=4 October 2016}} On 9 September, following the meeting between President Duterte and Indonesian President [[Joko Widodo]], an agreement was reached to pursue the Abu Sayyaf. The Philippine President said in a statement: {{quote|We agreed to encourage the earliest and effective implementation of cooperative frameworks to address security issues in maritime areas of common concern. We expressed commitment to take all necessary measures to ensure security in the Sulu Sea and maritime areas of common concern. There will be some interdiction by their armed forces and our armed forces and that is not really a warning but just a statement that we have decided to end this problem once and for all. Unlike the previous agreement with our neighbours, this time we will allows our neighbours to chase ships and pursue them even when they are in Philippine waters – "until such time that there is a competent Philippine authority who will take over in the chase. Maybe what's in my mind really is the hot pursuit and if the hot pursuit is done in the high seas, in the international waters, they can and they can even arrest or destroy them if they present a violent resistance". Malaysia will also be involved in this co-operation.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/indonesia/bahasa/englishedition/145747-maritime-cooperation-abu-sayyaf-kidnappings|title=Duterte wants Abu Sayyaf kidnappers 'blown up' at sea|author=Natashya Gutierrez|work=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Rappler|date=9 September 2016|accessdate=11 September 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160912064410/http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/indonesia/bahasa/englishedition/145747-maritime-cooperation-abu-sayyaf-kidnappings|archivedate=12 September 2016|deadurl=yes}}|Rodrigo Duterte, President of the Philippines}} However, the government of Indonesia decided to not launch a military operation in the southern Philippines, stating that not enough Philippine military personnel had been deployed. Indonesia's view was seconded by Malaysia.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/09/20/indonesia-won-t-enter-philippine-waters-despite-green-light.html |title=Indonesia won't enter Philippine waters despite green light |author=Haeril Halim |publisher=The Jakarta Post |date=20 September 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924171109/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/09/20/indonesia-won-t-enter-philippine-waters-despite-green-light.html |archivedate=24 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy}} Philippine military chief [[Ricardo Visaya]] warned the Abu Sayyaf that they would continue with further major military operations. The military chief gave notice to Abu Sayyaf members to surrender or be "neutralised", (killed or apprehended).{{cite web|url=http://www.malaya.com.ph/business-news/news/afp-chief-asg-surrender-or-die|title=AFP chief to ASG: Surrender or die|author=Victor Reyes|publisher=Malaya Business Insight|date=12 September 2016|accessdate=25 September 2016}} Some 20 Abu Sayyaf surrendered in Sumisip on 22 September.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2016/09/23/20-Abu-Sayyaf-militants-surrender-in-Philippines/9981474630916/|title=20 Abu Sayyaf militants surrender in Philippines|author=Ed Adamczyk|publisher=UPI.com|date=23 September 2016|accessdate=25 September 2016}} The day before, Philippine armed forces confiscated 200 speedboats used by the Abu Sayyaf in Basilan, Sulu, Tawi-Tawi and Zamboanga.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/817571/govt-seizes-200-high-powered-speedboats-from-abu-sayyaf|title=Gov't seizes 200 high-powered speedboats from Abu Sayyaf|author=Maila Ager|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=21 September 2016|accessdate=25 September 2016}} President Duterte rejected a proposal by [[Nur Misuari]], the leader of MNLF to include Abu Sayyaf in peace talks.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147403-philippines-duterte-no-amnesty-abu-sayyaf|title=Duterte: No amnesty for Abu Sayyaf|author=Pia Ranada|publisher=Rappler|date=26 September 2016|accessdate=27 September 2016}} On 27 September, another attempt to smuggle weapons to Abu Sayyaf was prevented by the [[Philippine National Police]] in [[San Juan, Metro Manila|San Juan City]]. Four people were arrested.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/09/27/1627928/high-powered-guns-abu-sayyaf-armm-execs-seized-san-juan|title=High-powered guns for Abu Sayyaf, ARMM execs seized in San Juan|author=AJ Bolando|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=27 September 2016|accessdate=27 September 2016}} By 14 October, the Philippine military had launched 579 military operations, 426 of which were focused to "neutralise" group members. 54 engagements resulted in 56 Abu Sayyaf members killed, 21 surrendered and 17 arrested.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/585068/news/nation/afp-59-bandits-killed-in-duterte-s-first-hundred-days|title=AFP: 59 bandits killed in Duterte's first hundred days|author=Erwin Colcol|publisher=GMA News|date=14 October 2016|accessdate=17 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/149393-abu-sayyaf-military-operations|title=AFP report: 94 Abu Sayyaf 'neutralized,' 14 hostages freed|publisher=Rappler|date=17 October 2016|accessdate=17 October 2016}} Abu Sayyaf fatalities then increased to 102, with seven more apprehended. Notable Abu Sayyaf leaders were killed, including Nelson Muktadil, Braun Muktadil, their sub-leader Mohammad Said, Jamiri Jawhari, Musanna Jamiri, the group spokesman Abu Rami and Alhabsy Misaya.{{cite web|url=http://www.maritime-executive.com/article/senior-abu-sayyaf-leader-offers-to-surrender|title=Senior Abu Sayyaf Leader Offers to Surrender|author=MarEx|publisher=The Maritime Executive|date=13 April 2017|accessdate=14 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://m.dw.com/en/philippine-marines-kill-abu-sayyaf-extremist-leader/a-38635850|title=Philippine marines kill Abu Sayyaf extremist leader|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=29 April 2017|accessdate=29 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/use-tools-war-vs-abu-sayyaf/291746/|title=Use all 'tools of war' vs Abu Sayyaf|author=Fernan Marasigan|publisher=The Manila Times|date=17 October 2016|accessdate=19 October 2016}} In addition, another 165 fast boats used for transport and kidnapping activities were confiscated. By 13 April 2017, 50 more ASG members had surrendered. In the same month, Philippine authorities discovered the presence of militants from Indonesia and Malaysia killed during the ongoing operations{{cite web|url=http://www.benarnews.org/english/news/indonesian/Lanao-del-Sur-04252017174353.html|title=Indonesians, Malaysian Among 37 Militants Killed in Philippine Military Strike: Officials|author1=Felipe Villamor|author2=Richel Umel|author3=Mark Navales|publisher=Benar News|date=25 April 2017|accessdate=29 April 2017}} (notable foreigners such as Sanusi, [[Zulkifli Abdhir]], Ibrahim Ali, Mohd Najib Husen and Mohisen were among the dead){{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/breaking-news/indonesian-militant-killed-in-philippines/news-story/170d252c5f5e0ac44fa295a3b8c46ed2|title=Indonesian militant killed in Philippines|work=AAP|publisher=news.com.au|date=24 November 2012|accessdate=29 April 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32157211|title=FBI confirms militant Marwan's death in Philippine raid|newspaper=BBC News|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=29 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/indonesian-bomb-ibrahim-ali-killed-by-military-in-mindanao/news-story/0b46cab4fb4a8d18fa162927f019b4b0|title=Indonesian bomb Ibrahim Ali killed by military in Mindanao|author=Deborah Cassrels|publisher=The Weekend Australian|date=30 November 2015|accessdate=29 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/malaysian-militant-killed-clashes-philippine-022912443.html|title=Malaysian militant killed in clashes with Philippine army, says report|work=The Malaysian Insider|publisher=Yahoo!
